newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: DAEWOO SHARES SLUMP AFTER PROFIT-WARNING.
newsitem.headline: DAEWOO SHARES SLUMP AFTER PROFIT-WARNING.

text.p: Shares in electronics firm Daewoo Electronics South Africa Ltd fell sharply on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange on Tuesday after the company issued a profit-warning.
At 1240 GMT, its shares were quoted at an intraday low of 242 cents -- down 56 cents or 18.8 percent from Monday's close -- on turnover of over 370,000 shares.
"It is down on the profit-warning that came out now. A lot of trade went through the market," a dealer said.
Daewoo said it would report a significant loss for the half year to June 30 due to tougher-than-expected market conditions.
It blamed high interest rates, delayed purchases of large household electrical goods and a flood of illegal imports.
"Shareholders are advised that, in respect of the interim results, a significant loss will be attributable to shareholders," the firm said in a statement.
Dealers said the latest news would batter the stock.
"I think it will come back more from these levels," one dealer said.
The counter traded at a year low of 126 cents on June 4, but recovered to a year high of 330 cents on July 29 in anticipation of an offshore cash injection which failed to materialise.
The firm's results will be published later in August.
